(32)

Zero-padding is applied symmetrically to the frequency spectrum E‚Å¢[fk]ùê∏delimited-[]subscriptùëìùëòE[f_{k}]italic_E [ italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] for the signal to stay real-valued after the inverse Fourier transformation

Epad‚Å¢[fk]={E‚Å¢[fk]for¬†‚Å¢k‚â§N20for¬†‚Å¢N2<k‚â§N2+ZE‚Å¢[fk‚àíZ]for¬†‚Å¢k>N2+Zsubscriptùê∏paddelimited-[]subscriptùëìùëòcasesùê∏delimited-[]subscriptùëìùëòfor¬†ùëòùëÅ20for¬†ùëÅ2ùëòùëÅ2ùëçùê∏delimited-[]subscriptùëìùëòùëçfor¬†ùëòùëÅ2ùëçE_{\text{pad}}[f_{k}]=\begin{cases}E[f_{k}]&\text{for }k\leq\frac{N}{2}\\ 0&\text{for }\frac{N}{2}<k\leq\frac{N}{2}+Z\\ E[f_{k-Z}]&\text{for }k>\frac{N}{2}+Z\end{cases}italic_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT pad end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] = { start_ROW start_CELL italic_E [ italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] end_CELL start_CELL for italic_k ‚â§ divide start_ARG italic_N end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL 0 end_CELL start_CELL for divide start_ARG italic_N end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG < italic_k ‚â§ divide start_ARG italic_N end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG + italic_Z end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL italic_E [ italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k - italic_Z end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] end_CELL start_CELL for italic_k > divide start_ARG italic_N end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG + italic_Z end_CELL end_ROW (33)

Finally, the inverse FFT (IFFT) is applied to the zero-padded frequency spectrum to convert it back into the time domain yielding the resampled time series

Eresamp‚Å¢[tj]=IFFT‚Å¢{Epad‚Å¢[fk]}=1N+Z‚Å¢‚àëk=0N+Z‚àí1Epad‚Å¢[fk]‚Å¢e2‚Å¢œÄ‚Å¢k‚Å¢jN+Z.subscriptùê∏resampdelimited-[]subscriptùë°ùëóIFFTsubscriptùê∏paddelimited-[]subscriptùëìùëò1ùëÅùëçsuperscriptsubscriptùëò0ùëÅùëç1subscriptùê∏paddelimited-[]subscriptùëìùëòsuperscriptùëí2ùúãùëòùëóùëÅùëçE_{\text{resamp}}[t_{j}]=\textbf{IFFT}\{E_{\text{pad}}[f_{k}]\}=\frac{1}{N+Z}% \sum_{k=0}^{N+Z-1}E_{\text{pad}}[f_{k}]e^{\frac{2\pi kj}{N+Z}}~{}.italic_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT resamp end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] = IFFT { italic_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT pad end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] } = divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_N + italic_Z end_ARG ‚àë start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_N + italic_Z - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT pad end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT divide start_ARG 2 italic_œÄ italic_k italic_j end_ARG start_ARG italic_N + italic_Z end_ARG end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT . (34)

This results in a new time series with a higher number of samples and a reduced time step, achieving the desired resampling effect. Such a simple resampling method only works without loss of information if frequencies above the Nyquist frequency are completely absent. If higher frequencies are present in the noise, whether due to artifacts or real signals, aliasing artifacts can occur. In such cases, a tapering window may be employed in the frequency domain to prevent artifacts introduced by a sharp transition to the padded region. Such a procedure does not prevent aliasing artifacts, i.e., the signal from the undersampled frequencies will still be wrongfully attributed to other frequencies. However, it removes ‚Äúringing‚Äù, i.e., oscillations caused by the sharp transition. If these higher frequencies become too strong, it makes sense to simply choose a higher sampling rate in the first place.

Appendix D Unshifted Absorption Spectra

In section VII the absorption spectra were shifted in energy to match the HEOM peak positions. These shifts were justified as being common practice when comparing to experimental absorption spectra. However, from a theoretical perspective, it is worth noting such shifts, because it is an error introduced by the method. Therefore, Fig.¬†11 shows the absorption spectra without the shifts and Table¬†2 reports the applied shifts.

Appendix E Summary of Super-Resolution Method and Modifications

To implement super-resolution technique, we mostly follow the procedure outlined in Ref.¬†91. The basic idea is to approximate the auto-correlation C‚Å¢(t)ùê∂ùë°C(t)italic_C ( italic_t ) with a series of Drude-Lorentz terms

C‚Å¢(t)=‚àëi,jŒªi‚Å¢j‚Å¢e‚àíŒ≥i‚Å¢t‚Å¢cos‚Å°(Œ©j‚Å¢t),ùê∂ùë°subscriptùëñùëósubscriptùúÜùëñùëósuperscriptùëísubscriptùõæùëñùë°subscriptŒ©ùëóùë°C(t)=\sum_{i,j}\lambda_{ij}e^{-\gamma_{i}t}\cos(\Omega_{j}t),italic_C ( italic_t ) = ‚àë start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i , italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œª start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_Œ≥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_cos ( roman_Œ© start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t ) , (41)

where Œªi‚Å¢jsubscriptùúÜùëñùëó\lambda_{ij}italic_Œª start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are the expansion coefficients, Œ≥isubscriptùõæùëñ\gamma_{i}italic_Œ≥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT the linewidths, and œâjsubscriptùúîùëó\omega_{j}italic_œâ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT the respective frequencies. This expression can be rewritten in matrix form as a linear algebra problem

Ck=Ai‚Å¢j‚Å¢k‚Å¢Œªi‚Å¢j,subscriptùê∂ùëòsubscriptùê¥ùëñùëóùëòsubscriptùúÜùëñùëóC_{k}=A_{ijk}\lambda_{ij},italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œª start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , (42)

where Ck=C‚Å¢(tk)subscriptùê∂ùëòùê∂subscriptùë°ùëòC_{k}=C(t_{k})italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_C ( italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) represents the discretized correlation function at different time points and Ai‚Å¢j‚Å¢k=e‚àíŒ≥i‚Å¢tk‚Å¢cos‚Å°(Œ©j‚Å¢tk)subscriptùê¥ùëñùëóùëòsuperscriptùëísubscriptùõæùëñsubscriptùë°ùëòsubscriptŒ©ùëósubscriptùë°ùëòA_{ijk}=e^{-\gamma_{i}t_{k}}\cos(\Omega_{j}t_{k})italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_Œ≥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_cos ( roman_Œ© start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) denotes the coefficient matrix. Here, the indices i,j,ùëñùëói,j,italic_i , italic_j , and kùëòkitalic_k correspond to the grid points for damping coefficients, frequencies, and time, respectively. To ensure the system is underdetermined and to allow for the selection of a suitable solution, the grid of Œ≥isubscriptùõæùëñ\gamma_{i}italic_Œ≥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Œ©jsubscriptŒ©ùëó\Omega_{j}roman_Œ© start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is chosen such that there are significantly more basis functions than time samples. This underdetermination enables us to ‚Äúchoose‚Äù a suitable solution by introducing regularization. However, for the complicated FMO spectral density studied in this work, the total variation norm proposed for regularization in Ref.91 did not perform well. It resulted in many unphysical, negative peaks in the spectral density. To address this issue, we replaced the total variation norm with a penalty for negative peaks. Specifically, we rephrased the problem as a minimization of the following objective function

a‚Å¢‚ÄñAi‚Å¢j‚Å¢k‚Å¢Œªi‚Å¢j‚àíCk‚Äñ2+b‚Å¢‚ÄñŒªi‚Å¢j‚Äñ1+c‚Å¢‚àëi‚Å¢j|Œªi‚Å¢j|‚àíŒªi‚Å¢j,ùëésubscriptnormsubscriptùê¥ùëñùëóùëòsubscriptùúÜùëñùëósubscriptùê∂ùëò2ùëèsubscriptnormsubscriptùúÜùëñùëó1ùëêsubscriptùëñùëósubscriptùúÜùëñùëósubscriptùúÜùëñùëóa\|A_{ijk}\lambda_{ij}-C_{k}\|_{2}+b\|\lambda_{ij}\|_{1}+c\sum_{ij}|\lambda_{% ij}|-\lambda_{ij},italic_a ‚à• italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œª start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚à• start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_b ‚à• italic_Œª start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚à• start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_c ‚àë start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_Œª start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | - italic_Œª start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , (43)

where ‚àëi‚Å¢j|Œªi‚Å¢j|‚àíŒªi‚Å¢jsubscriptùëñùëósubscriptùúÜùëñùëósubscriptùúÜùëñùëó\sum_{ij}|\lambda_{ij}|-\lambda_{ij}‚àë start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_Œª start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | - italic_Œª start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is the negative penalty. The parameters a,b,ùëéùëèa,b,italic_a , italic_b , and cùëêcitalic_c need to be chosen to balance the terms in the optimization. For the calculations in this work a=1‚ãÖ104ùëé‚ãÖ1superscript104a=1\cdot 10^{4}italic_a = 1 ‚ãÖ 10 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 4 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, b=1ùëè1b=1italic_b = 1, and c=0.1ùëê0.1c=0.1italic_c = 0.1 were used. Instead of using the two-step iterative shrinkage tresholding (TwIST) [103] algorithm as proposed in Ref.¬†91, which requires determining the proximal operator for the negative penalty, we opted for the limited memory Broyden‚ÄìFletcher‚ÄìGoldfarb‚ÄìShanno (L-BFGS) optimization [104], specifically the implementation in the PyTorch library [105] with GPU acceleration. This choice allows for more straightforward handling of the penalty without additional complexity. For our calculations, we used a grid in frequency space Œ©jsubscriptŒ©ùëó\Omega_{j}roman_Œ© start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT with a range from 0 to 0.2 eV and intervals of 5‚ãÖ10‚àí5‚ãÖ5superscript1055\cdot 10^{-5}5 ‚ãÖ 10 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 5 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT eV. As well as a range of linewidths Œ≥isubscriptùõæùëñ\gamma_{i}italic_Œ≥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT from 1 to 200 cm-1 with intervals of 0.5 cm-1. These very fine-grained grids were necessary to achieve good performance with our reference spectral density, but also led to very high computational costs. After the optimization, a debiasing step is performed. Only the top contributing modes are selected and a least squares optimization is performed with just those modes. In the present case we modified the procedure again and used a non-negative least squared optimization to avoid the negative peaks. Furthermore, we could not obtain suitable solutions with just a few peaks, so that we had to set the threshold for included peaks to a very low value of 5‚ãÖ10‚àí8‚ãÖ5superscript1085\cdot 10^{-8}5 ‚ãÖ 10 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 8 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. The spectral density is then reconstructed from the determined parameters as

J‚Å¢(œâ)=2‚Å¢œÄ‚Å¢œâ‚Å¢‚àëi,j(Œªi,j‚Å¢Œ≥iŒ≥i2+(œâ+Œ©j)2+Œªi,j‚Å¢Œ≥iŒ≥i2+(œâ‚àíŒ©j)2)ùêΩùúî2ùúãùúîsubscriptùëñùëósubscriptùúÜùëñùëósubscriptùõæùëñsuperscriptsubscriptùõæùëñ2superscriptùúîsubscriptŒ©ùëó2subscriptùúÜùëñùëósubscriptùõæùëñsuperscriptsubscriptùõæùëñ2superscriptùúîsubscriptŒ©ùëó2J(\omega)=2\pi\omega\sum_{i,j}\left(\frac{\lambda_{i,j}\gamma_{i}}{\gamma_{i}^% {2}+(\omega+\Omega_{j})^{2}}+\frac{\lambda_{i,j}\gamma_{i}}{\gamma_{i}^{2}+(% \omega-\Omega_{j})^{2}}\right)italic_J ( italic_œâ ) = 2 italic_œÄ italic_œâ ‚àë start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i , italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( divide start_ARG italic_Œª start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i , italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œ≥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_Œ≥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + ( italic_œâ + roman_Œ© start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG + divide start_ARG italic_Œª start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i , italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œ≥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_Œ≥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + ( italic_œâ - roman_Œ© start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG ) (44)

Fig.¬†12 shows the performance of the super-resolution technique compared to the Gaussian damping that was determined to be the overall best of the FFT methods in Sec.¬†V. The cutoff time tcsubscriptùë°ùëêt_{c}italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for the super-resolution technique corresponds to the length of the autocorrelation included in Eq.¬†42, which is a cutoff similar to the step function. In the theoretical case, the super-resolution scheme shows the best performance for low tcsubscriptùë°ùëêt_{c}italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, but stops improving after roughly tc=6subscriptùë°ùëê6t_{c}=6italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 6 ps. Increasing aùëéaitalic_a from the objective function in Eq.¬†43 would force solutions closer to the given autocorrelation, thereby improving the results for larger tcsubscriptùë°ùëêt_{c}italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT in the theoretical case but also the chance for overfitting in noisy cases. In the noisy cases, the super-resolution technique performs similarly but does not achieve as low a MAE as the Gaussian damping.

Similar to Fig.¬†7 in Sec.¬†V, Fig.¬†13 contrasts the spectral densities determined by super-resolution and Gaussian damping with the original spectral density. Panel a shows spectral densities obtained from the theoretical autocorrelation function, while panel b for an autocorrelation functions based on a 100 ps noise trajectory. The cutoff times were chosen to be 5 ps for the Gaussian damping and 3 ps for super-resolution case based on the optimal performance displayed in Fig.¬†12b for the 100 ps case. It can generally be seen that the Gaussian damping resolves details somewhat more accurate, while the super-resolution results align slightly better in terms of peak heights. Overall, both methods offer very similar performance. However, the quality of the super-resolution results strongly depend on a good choice of regularization on top of tcsubscriptùë°ùëêt_{c}italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. For example, the regularization proposed in Ref.¬†91 lead to completely unusable results for the reference spectral density considered here. In the present case, it was also necessary to consider a very fine-grained grid of line shapes and peak positions, making the calculation computationally demanding. While it is likely, that an appropriate regularization term could theoretically be found to make the super-resolution technique outperform Gaussian damping, doing so would be very challenging in any realistic scenarios where the correct spectral density is unknown. In most cases, the FFT-based damping approach will be preferable, as it is very easy to compute and only depends on one parameter, i.e., the cutoff time tcsubscriptùë°ùëêt_{c}italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. A very simple way for determining tcsubscriptùë°ùëêt_{c}italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT was described in Sec.¬†V.

Appendix F Recipes for Best Practices

F.1 Spectral densities from time series of site energies

In this subsection, we summarize the results of section V and present a step-by-step recipe for determining spectral density from limited data, such as excited state calculations along MD or QM/MM trajectories.

  1. 1.

    Choose a time step as large as possible while still resolving all relevant frequencies according to [86, 87, 88]

    œânyq=2‚Å¢œÄ‚Å¢fs2=œÄŒî‚Å¢t.subscriptùúînyq2ùúãsubscriptùëìs2ùúãŒîùë°\omega_{\text{nyq}}=2\pi\frac{f_{\text{s}}}{2}=\frac{\pi}{\Delta t}.italic_œâ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT nyq end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 2 italic_œÄ divide start_ARG italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG = divide start_ARG italic_œÄ end_ARG start_ARG roman_Œî italic_t end_ARG . (45)

    For chlorophyll molecules or similar, the relevant frequencies reach up to about 0.2 eV, which means a time step of 10 fs is sufficient.

  2. 2.

    For the length of the simulation, the longer, the better. The constraining factor is the computation time.

  3. 3.

    Calculate the autocorrelation function according to [55]

    C‚Å¢(tj)=1N‚àíj‚Å¢‚àëi=1N‚àíjŒî‚Å¢E‚Å¢(ti+tj)‚Å¢Œî‚Å¢E‚Å¢(ti).ùê∂subscriptùë°ùëó1ùëÅùëósuperscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëÅùëóŒîùê∏subscriptùë°ùëñsubscriptùë°ùëóŒîùê∏subscriptùë°ùëñC(t_{j})=\frac{1}{N-j}\sum_{i=1}^{N-j}\Delta E(t_{i}+t_{j})\Delta E(t_{i})~{}.italic_C ( italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_N - italic_j end_ARG ‚àë start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_N - italic_j end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_Œî italic_E ( italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) roman_Œî italic_E ( italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) . (46)
  4. 4.

    Find the time tcsubscriptùë°ùëêt_{c}italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT at which the autocorrelation function starts being dominated by noise. This can be done, for example, by looking at the moving absolute average (see Fig.¬†5b) and does not have to be very accurate.

  5. 5.

    Apply a Gaussian damping function exp‚Å°(‚àí(t/tc)2)superscriptùë°subscriptùë°ùëê2\exp(-(t/t_{c})^{2})roman_exp ( - ( italic_t / italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) with cutoff time tcsubscriptùë°ùëêt_{c}italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT to the autocorrelation function [64].

  6. 6.

    Perform A Discrete Cosine Transform of C(t) and multiply the results by Œ≤‚Å¢œâ/œÄùõΩùúîùúã\beta\omega/\piitalic_Œ≤ italic_œâ / italic_œÄ to get the spectral density. See Appendix A on how to use an FFT instead.

  1. 1.

    As a start, one needs to define a time-independent Hamiltonian of the system

(47)
  2. 2.

    For every site jùëójitalic_j, generate a noise trajectory with the desired simulation length, that follows the desired spectral density Jj‚Å¢(œâ)subscriptùêΩùëóùúîJ_{j}(\omega)italic_J start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_œâ ). See next recipe for details.

    Propagate the wave function according to

    |œà~‚Å¢(t+Œî‚Å¢t)‚ü©=S^‚Å¢(t)‚Å¢U^~‚Å¢(t+Œî‚Å¢t,t)‚Å¢|œà~‚Å¢(t)‚ü©,ket~ùúìùë°Œîùë°^ùëÜùë°~^ùëàùë°Œîùë°ùë°ket~ùúìùë°\ket{\tilde{\psi}(t+\Delta t)}=\hat{S}(t)\tilde{\hat{U}}(t+\Delta t,t)\ket{% \tilde{\psi}(t)}~{},| start_ARG over~ start_ARG italic_œà end_ARG ( italic_t + roman_Œî italic_t ) end_ARG ‚ü© = over^ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG ( italic_t ) over~ start_ARG over^ start_ARG italic_U end_ARG end_ARG ( italic_t + roman_Œî italic_t , italic_t ) | start_ARG over~ start_ARG italic_œà end_ARG ( italic_t ) end_ARG ‚ü© , (48)

    or choose STsuperscriptùëÜùëáS^{T}italic_S start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT or SM‚Å¢LsuperscriptùëÜùëÄùêøS^{ML}italic_S start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_M italic_L end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT for TNISE or MLNIE, respectively.   4. 4.

  5. 5.

    Be cautious when using TNISE concerning the early thermalization issue detailed in Section VI.

    Determine the target power spectrum of the desired spectral density J‚Å¢(œâ)ùêΩùúîJ(\omega)italic_J ( italic_œâ ) as

    Perform a Fast Fourier Transform (FFT) of the white noise and divide it by the square root of the time step d‚Å¢tùëëùë°dtitalic_d italic_t to obtain the noise in frequency domain

    Œ∑~W‚Å¢(œâ)=FFT‚Å¢(Œ∑W‚Å¢(t))d‚Å¢t.superscript~ùúÇùëäùúîFFTsuperscriptùúÇùëäùë°ùëëùë°\tilde{\eta}^{W}(\omega)=\frac{\textbf{FFT}(\eta^{W}(t))}{\sqrt{dt}}~{}.over~ start_ARG italic_Œ∑ end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_W end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_œâ ) = divide start_ARG FFT ( italic_Œ∑ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_W end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) ) end_ARG start_ARG square-root start_ARG italic_d italic_t end_ARG end_ARG .     Œ∑~T‚Å¢(œâ)=Œ∑~W‚Å¢(œâ)‚Å¢C~T‚Å¢(œâ).superscript~ùúÇùëáùúîsuperscript~ùúÇùëäùúîsuperscript~ùê∂ùëáùúî\tilde{\eta}^{T}(\omega)=\tilde{\eta}^{W}(\omega)\sqrt{\tilde{C}^{T}(\omega)}~% {}.over~ start_ARG italic_Œ∑ end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_œâ ) = over~ start_ARG italic_Œ∑ end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_W end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_œâ ) square-root start_ARG over~ start_ARG italic_C end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_œâ ) end_ARG .     Determine the real part of the inverse FFT resulting in the target noise Œ∑T‚Å¢(t)superscriptùúÇùëáùë°\eta^{T}(t)italic_Œ∑ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t )

    Drop the second half of the noise to obtain noise of the desired length. This trick needs to be performed since the algorithm generates periodic trajectories otherwise.
